name: Automatisation de Facturation Complète : Airtable, QuickBooks & Stripe
description:
# Ce modèle n8n de [Intuz](https://www.intuz.com/) fournit une solution complète et automatisée pour la facturation complète, orchestrant un flux sans faille entre Airtable, QuickBooks et Stripe. 

C'est l'automatisation ultime de la vente à l'encaissement. Lorsqu'un accord dans Airtable est marqué "Approuvé pour Facturation", ce flux de travail synchronise intelligemment les données clients entre QuickBooks et Stripe (les créant s'ils n'existent pas), génère une facture officielle QuickBooks, crée un lien de paiement Stripe, puis met à jour l'enregistrement Airtable d'origine avec tous les nouveaux ID et liens. Éliminez la saisie manuelle des données et gardez vos systèmes parfaitement synchronisés.


## Pour qui est ce flux de travail ? 

1. Équipes Financières, Comptables et Opérationnelles
2. Équipes SalesOps et RevOps
3. Propriétaires et Fondateurs de Petites Entreprises
4. Agences et Freelancers


## Comment ça fonctionne :
**1. Déclencheur Airtable & Porte d'Approbation :** Le flux de travail commence lorsqu'un enregistrement dans votre base Airtable est mis à jour. Un nœud If vérifie immédiatement si le champ Statut est défini sur "Approuvé pour Facturation". Si ce n'est pas le cas, le flux de travail pour cet élément s'arrête.

**2. Synchronisation Client (QuickBooks & Stripe) :**
- Le flux de travail recherche le client à la fois dans QuickBooks et Stripe en utilisant les détails d'Airtable.
- En utilisant des nœuds If, il vérifie intelligemment si le client existe. Si un client n'est pas trouvé sur l'une ou l'autre plateforme, il en crée un nouveau. Cette logique de "trouver ou créer" empêche les enregistrements en double.

**3. Mettre à jour Airtable avec des ID :** Une fois que les ID clients de QuickBooks et Stripe sont sécurisés (soit trouvés, soit nouvellement créés), le flux de travail met à jour l'enregistrement Airtable d'origine avec ces nouveaux ID pour référence future.

**4. Générer les Finances :**
- Lien de Paiement Stripe : Il envoie une requête HTTP à Stripe pour créer un lien de paiement unique et prêt à l'emploi pour le montant spécifié.
- Facture QuickBooks : Il récupère votre liste de produits depuis QuickBooks, trouve l'élément correspondant dans l'enregistrement Airtable et génère une facture formelle et détaillée.

**5. Clore la Boucle** : Dans la dernière étape, le flux de travail met à jour l'enregistrement Airtable une dernière fois pour :
- Ajouter le numéro de Facture QuickBooks.
- Ajouter le Lien de Paiement Stripe.
- Changer le Statut en "Facturé."


## Instructions de Configuration Étape par Étape
C'est un flux de travail avancé. Suivez ces étapes de configuration avec soin.

**1. Connectez Vos Identifiants**
- Airtable : Créez et connectez un Jeton d'Accès Personnel avec les portées data.records:read et data.records:write.
- QuickBooks : Connectez votre compte QuickBooks en ligne en utilisant des identifiants OAuth2.
- Stripe : Connectez votre compte Stripe en utilisant votre Clé Secrète.

**2. Configuration de la Base Airtable (Cruciale)**
Votre base Airtable doit avoir une table avec les colonnes suivantes. Les noms doivent correspondre exactement :

- Nom de l'Accord (Texte)
- Nom du Client (Texte)
- Email du Client (Email)
- Statut (Sélection unique avec options : Brouillon,
- Approuvé pour Facturation, Facturé)
- ID Client QuickBooks (Texte)
- ID Client Stripe (Texte)
- Lien de Paiement Stripe (URL)
- Numéro de Facture QuickBooks (Texte)
- ID de Prix Stripe (Texte - L'ID API de votre prix dans Stripe, par exemple, price_123...)
- Quantité (Nombre)
- Nom du Produit QuickBooks (Texte)
- Créé (Heure de Création) - Ceci est utilisé par le déclencheur.

**3. Configurer les Nœuds n8n**
- Tous les Nœuds Airtable : Dans chaque nœud Airtable, sélectionnez votre Base et Table dans les listes déroulantes.
- Obtenez tous les produits QuickBooks (Nœud de Requête HTTP) :
Vous devez remplacer {YOUR_QUICKBOOKS_COMPANY_ID} dans l'URL par votre véritable ID d'Entreprise QuickBooks (également connu sous le nom d'ID de Domaine).

**4. Activez le Flux de Travail**
Enregistrez le flux de travail et activez l'interrupteur Actif sur "on". Le flux de travail se déclenchera désormais chaque fois que le champ Créé est mis à jour pour un enregistrement dans votre base Airtable.


## Conseils de Personnalisation
- Changer le Statut de Déclenchement : Si vous utilisez un statut différent de "Approuvé pour Facturation", mettez simplement à jour la valeur dans le nœud "IF - Vérification de Statut".
- Modifier les Détails de la Facture : Vous pouvez personnaliser la Description ou d'autres détails des lignes dans le nœud "Créer une facture" (QuickBooks) en tirant plus de champs de votre enregistrement Airtable.
- Ajouter des Notifications par Email : Pour notifier un client lorsque sa facture est prête, ajoutez un nœud Gmail ou SendGrid après le dernier nœud de Mise à Jour Airtable. Vous pouvez inclure le Lien de Paiement Stripe et un PDF de la facture QuickBooks directement dans l'email.
- Gestion Avancée des Erreurs : Pour un environnement de production, envisagez de connecter la sortie fausse des différents nœuds IF ou d'utiliser le paramètre de flux de travail .onError() pour envoyer une alerte Slack ou par email si un client ne peut pas être trouvé ou si un appel API échoue.


## Support
Pour un soutien supplémentaire, ou pour développer un flux de travail personnalisé, contactez :

- Site Web : https://www.intuz.com/services
- Email : getstarted@intuz.com
- LinkedIn : https://www.linkedin.com/company/intuz
- Commencez : https://n8n.partnerlinks.io/intuz

## Pour l'Automatisation de Flux de Travail Personnalisé
Cliquez ici- [Commencer](https://www.intuz.com/get-started)

parameters.CustomerRef: ={{ $('Update Quickbooks and Stripe Customer Ids').item.json.fields['QuickBooks Customer ID'] }}

parameters.content:
### Step 1: Airtable Trigger 🚦📋

This node triggers the workflow whenever there is a change in the **Created** column, effectively activating when new data is added.

Why this step is important:

- ⏰ Automatically starts the workflow on new entries.
- 📈 Monitors real-time changes for timely processing.
- 🔄 Ensures your automation responds instantly to new Airtable data.

It’s the step that keeps your workflow synced with your Airtable updates. 🔔✨

### Step 2: Airtable Search Records 🔍📋

This node searches and retrieves all records from a specific Airtable table.

Why this step is important:

- 🔎 Gathers complete data from the table for processing.
- 📊 Enables further filtering, updating, or analysis within the workflow.
- 🗂️ Provides a snapshot of all relevant records at once.

It’s the step that collects your data foundation for the automation ahead. 🧱✨

### Step 3: Status Check (If Node) ✅❌

This node checks whether the **Status** field is set to **'Approved for Invoicing'**.

- **True:** Continues with the workflow.
- **False:** Gracefully exits the workflow.

Why this step is important:

- ✔️ Ensures only approved records proceed for invoicing.
- 🛑 Prevents processing of draft or already invoiced data.
- 🔄 Maintains workflow efficiency and accuracy.

### Graceful Exit (No-Op Node) 🛑✨

This **No Operation** node acts as a graceful exit point for items whose status is **not** 'Approved for Invoicing'.

Why this step is important:

- 🛡️ Prevents further processing of unapproved records.
- 🔄 Ensures the workflow ends cleanly without errors.
- 🧹 Keeps workflow logic clear and organized.

It’s the safe landing spot that quietly ends the flow when no action is needed. 🚪✅

### Step 4: Find Customer in QuickBooks 🔍👤

This node uses the **Find Customer** operation to search for a customer in QuickBooks based on the **Display Name** parameter.

Why this step is important:

- 🔎 Quickly locates existing customers by their display name.
- ✅ Helps avoid duplicate customer records.
- 📋 Ensures accurate linking of invoices and estimates to the right customer.

It’s the step that verifies customer existence to maintain clean and organized data. 🧹✨

### Step 5: Customer Existence Check (If Node) ❓✅❌

This node checks whether a customer exists in QuickBooks.

- **False:** Customer exists; workflow continues without creating a new customer.
- **True:** Customer does **not** exist; triggers creation of a new customer before continuing.

Why this step is important:

- 🔄 Directs the workflow to create a customer only when needed.
- 🛡️ Prevents duplicate customer entries.
- ⚙️ Ensures smooth, logical progression of the automation.

It’s the decision point that manages customer creation intelligently. 🔀✨

Create Customer in QuickBooks ➕👤

This node uses the **Create Customer** operation to add a new customer to QuickBooks using details from Airtable.

Why this step is important:

- 🆕 Adds new customers automatically when they don’t exist.
- 📥 Keeps your QuickBooks customer database current and accurate.
- 🔗 Links customer records to subsequent invoices or estimates.

It’s the step that fills gaps in your customer list, ensuring seamless data flow. ✍️✨

### Step 6: Merge Customer Data Node 🔗📊

This node merges data from existing customers with newly created customer records.

Why this step is important:

- 🔄 Combines customer information into a single dataset.
- 📋 Ensures continuity and completeness of customer details.
- ⚙️ Prepares unified data for downstream workflow steps.

It’s the step that brings together all customer data for seamless processing. 🤝✨

### Step 7: Stripe Customer ID Check (If Node) 🔍💳

This node checks whether the **Stripe Customer ID** already exists for users in Airtable.

- **True:** Stripe Customer ID exists; proceeds to find the customer.
- **False:** Stripe Customer ID does not exist; continues with the workflow to create or update as needed.

Why this step is important:

- ✅ Prevents duplicate Stripe customer entries.
- 🔄 Directs the workflow along the correct path based on Stripe data.
- ⚙️ Maintains data integrity across systems.

It’s the decision point that manages Stripe customer handling efficiently. 🔀✨

Find Customer in Stripe 🔍💳

This node uses the **Find Customer** operation to search for a customer in Stripe based on the **Stripe Customer ID**.

Why this step is important:

- 🔎 Quickly locates the customer record in Stripe.
- ✅ Ensures accurate synchronization between your systems.
- 📋 Prevents duplicate customer creation in Stripe.

It’s the step that verifies Stripe customer existence to maintain clean and consistent billing data. 🧹✨

### Step 8: Merge Stripe Customer Data Node 🔗💳

This node merges data from the **If Node** decision with the newly retrieved customer data from the **Stripe - Find Customer** node.

Why this step is important:

- 🔄 Combines decision results with fresh customer information.
- 📊 Ensures unified data for further processing in the workflow.
- ⚙️ Maintains data consistency across Stripe and Airtable.

It’s the step that integrates conditional logic with actual customer details for smooth automation. 🤝✨

### Step 9: Stripe Customer Existence Check (If Node) 🔍✅❌

This node checks whether a Stripe customer exists based on the **name**.

- **True:** Customer does **not** exist; proceeds to create a new customer.
- **False:** Customer exists; continues with the workflow without creating.

Why this step is important:

- ✅ Prevents duplicate Stripe customer creation.
- 🔄 Directs workflow to create customers only when necessary.
- ⚙️ Ensures clean and accurate Stripe customer data.

It’s the decision gate that manages Stripe customer creation smartly. 🔀✨

Create Customer in Stripe ➕💳

This node uses the **Create Customer** operation to add a new customer in Stripe using the **name** and **email address** from Airtable.

Why this step is important:

- 🆕 Automatically adds new customers to Stripe when they don’t exist.
- 📧 Uses accurate customer details from Airtable for Stripe records.
- 🔗 Ensures Stripe customer data is up-to-date and linked correctly.

It’s the step that expands your Stripe customer base seamlessly from Airtable data. ✍️✨

### Step 10: Merge New Stripe Customer Data Node 🔗💳

This node merges data from the previous **If Node** with the newly created Stripe customer data.

Why this step is important:

- 🔄 Combines decision results with fresh customer creation data.
- 📊 Provides a unified dataset for downstream processing.
- ⚙️ Ensures consistency and completeness of customer information.

It’s the step that integrates newly created Stripe customer details seamlessly into the workflow. 🤝✨

### Step 11: Search Records in Airtable 🔍📋

This node searches for complete records in the Airtable table based on the **email address** from the previous merge node.

Why this step is important:

- 🔎 Retrieves full user data linked to the email.
- 📊 Ensures accurate and updated information for the workflow.
- ⚙️ Enables precise matching and further processing.

It’s the step that pulls detailed Airtable records to keep your automation data-rich and reliable. 📚✨

nodes.name: Update Quickbooks and Stripe Customer Ids

parameters.content:
### Step 12: Update Records in Airtable ✏️🔄

This node updates the Airtable records to add or modify the **QuickBooks Customer ID** and **Stripe Customer ID** for the corresponding users.

Why this step is important:

- 🆕 Keeps Airtable data synchronized with QuickBooks and Stripe.
- 🔗 Ensures accurate linking of customer IDs across platforms.
- 🔄 Maintains data integrity for future workflows and reports.

It’s the step that closes the loop by updating your source data with key customer identifiers. ✅✨

### Step 13: Generate Stripe Payment Link (HTTP Request) 🔗💳

This node sends a **POST** HTTP request with the **Stripe Price ID** and **quantity** from Airtable to generate a ready-to-pay link.

Why this step is important:

- 🛒 Creates a payment link dynamically based on order details.
- 🔗 Enables easy and secure customer checkout.
- ⚡ Automates payment initiation directly from your data.

It’s the step that turns order info into a clickable payment link, simplifying the checkout process. 🔥✨

### Step 14: Fetch All Products from QuickBooks (HTTP Request) 📦🔍

This node sends an HTTP request to retrieve all products from QuickBooks.

Why this step is important:

- 📋 Gathers the full product catalog for reference or processing.
- 🔄 Keeps your workflow updated with the latest product information.
- ⚙️ Enables product data integration across your automation.

It’s the step that pulls your product inventory into the workflow for seamless management. 📦✨

### Step 15: Filter Products by Airtable Data (Code Node) ⚙️🔍

This node runs custom code to filter and return only the product details that exist in Airtable.

Why this step is important:

- 🎯 Narrows down the product list to relevant items.
- 🔄 Improves workflow efficiency by processing only necessary data.
- 📋 Ensures accuracy by matching QuickBooks products with Airtable records.

It’s the step that refines your product data for targeted automation. 🧹✨

### Step 16: Create Invoice in QuickBooks 🧾✨

This node uses the **Create Invoice** operation to generate an invoice in QuickBooks based on data from previous nodes.

Why this step is important:

- 📄 Converts collected data into a formal invoice.
- 🔗 Links invoices to the correct customers and products.
- ⚡ Automates billing and record-keeping processes.

It’s the step that issues the official invoice, completing the sales cycle. ✅✨

nodes.name: Update Stripe Payment Link and Quickbooks Invoice #

parameters.content:
### Step 17: Update Airtable Records ✏️🔄

This node updates Airtable records with the newly created **Stripe Payment Link** and **QuickBooks Invoice #**.

Why this step is important:

- 🔗 Keeps Airtable synchronized with payment and invoice details.
- 📋 Provides easy access to transaction information within Airtable.
- ⚡ Enhances tracking and reporting accuracy.

It’s the step that ensures your source data reflects the latest billing status. 📈✨

### Step 18: Workflow Completion (No-Op Node) ✅🎉

This **No Operation** node marks the successful completion of the entire workflow.

Why this step is important:

- 🎯 Signifies a clean and error-free end to the process.
- 🛡️ Prevents unintended actions after workflow completion.
- 🔄 Helps maintain clear workflow structure and readability.

It’s the final step that confirms your automation ran smoothly from start to finish. 🎬✨

### Prerequisites ⚙️🔗

#### AIRTABLE
- Create and connect your Airtable account using a **Personal Access Token**.
- Create a table with the following columns:
  - **Deal Name** - Short representation of each record.
  - **Client Name** - Name of the client/customer.
  - **Client Email** - Email of the client/customer.
  - **Status** - Status of the deal (Draft, Approved for Invoicing, Invoiced).
  - **QuickBooks Customer ID** - ID of the client in QuickBooks.
  - **Stripe Customer ID** - ID of the client in Stripe.
  - **Stripe Payment Link** - Payment link from Stripe.
  - **QuickBooks Invoice #** - Invoice number from QuickBooks.
  - **Stripe Price Id** - Price ID of the product selected by the client in Stripe.
  - **Quantity** - Quantity of the product selected by the client.
  - **QuickBooks Product Name** - Name of the product from QuickBooks.
  - **Created** - Created timestamp.

- Select the base and table in the **Airtable Trigger** node.
- Connect and select the same base and table in all required Airtable nodes.

#### QUICKBOOKS
- Create and connect credentials using **OAuth2 authorization** in QuickBooks.
- Use the same credentials across all QuickBooks nodes.
- Add your company ID in the URL in the **Get all Quickbook products** node

#### STRIPE
- Generate and connect your Stripe account using the **Secret Key**.
- Use these credentials in all required Stripe nodes.

### Get in Touch

Please feel free to reachout to us, if you need any help in settin up this workflow.

We can also help customize workflow pet the use-case. 

Reach out us at: getstarted@intuz.com

Website: https://www.intuz.com/

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
